variant.question: An increase in ambient temperature:

options.text: generally reduces performance.
does not influence performance.
increases or decreases performance depending on the aircraft type.
increases performance.

variant.question: What effect does the air density have on the take-off and landing distances of an aeroplane?

options.text: With decreasing density altitude, take-off distance will decrease and landing distance will decrease.
With increasing density, take-off distance will increase and landing distance will increase.
With increasing density altitude, take-off distance will decrease and landing distance will decrease.
With increasing density, take-off distance will decrease and landing distance will increase.

variant.question:
If the aircraft takes off by using the wet V1 instead of the dry V1, what is the effect on the TODR and on the obstacle clearance?
 The TODR ___ and the obstacle clearance is ___.

options.text: increases; degraded
decreases; improved
increases; improved
decreases; degraded

variant.question: A decrease in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance:

options.text: An increased take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
A reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb performance
A reduced take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
An increased take-off distance and improved initial climb performance

variant.question: A decrease in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance:

options.text: an increased take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance.
a reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb performance.
a reduced take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance.
an increased take-off distance and improved initial climb performance.

variant.question: The following parameters affect the take-off ground run: - 1. decreasing take-off mass - 2. increasing take-off mass - 3. increasing density - 4. decreasing density - 5. increasing flap setting - 6. decreasing flap setting - 7. increasing pressure altitude - 8. decreasing pressure altitude - Which parameters will decrease the take-off ground run?
V~<span>X ~and V~Y~ with take-off flaps will be:

options.text: lower than that for clean configuration.
same as that for clean configuration.
higher than that for clean configuration.
changed so that V~X~ increases and V~<span style="font-size:10.5px">Y~ decreases compared to clean configuration.

variant.question:
Take-off on a runway with standing water, with a depth of 0.5 cm
Compared to a dry runway, field length limited mass will

options.text: decrease, with a decreased V1.
increase, with a reduced V1.
remain the same, with a reduced V1.
decrease, with an increased V1.

variant.question: Take-off run required for a jet aircraft, with one engine inoperative is

options.text: brake release point to midpoint between VLOF and 35 ft.
brake release point to 15 ft.
brake release point to 35 ft.
the same as for all engines.

variant.question: What is the 2 second interval for in the engine failure take-off?

options.text: To recognise and react to the engine failure by V1.
It is considered in the all engines take-off only.
Permits the recognition of the engine failure.
The pilot must apply the brakes one second before V1 to stop within the ASDA.

variant.question: Which of the following will probably result in the greatest increase in take-off distance for a single-engined piston aeroplane?

options.text: Tailwind; upslope; high surface temperature.
Headwind; downslope; high surface temperature.
Headwind; downslope; low surface temperature.
Tailwind; downslope; high surface temperature.

variant.question: During take-off, the time between critical engine failure and V1 (recognition time) is assumed to be approximately

options.text: 2 seconds.
5 seconds.
6 seconds.
0 seconds.

variant.question:
Which factors might cause V2 to be limited by VMCA?
 
1) large flap angles.
 
2) small flap angles.
 
3) high air pressure.
 
4) low air pressure.
 
5) high aircraft weights.
6) low aircraft weights.
For an aeroplane in Performance Class B the following factors must be applied in determining the take-off distance from dry grass and wet pavement respectively:
For an aircraft powered by turbo-prop engines the landing distance required at an alternate will be

options.text: the same as that required at a destination aerodrome.
either less than that required at a destination aerodrome or the same depending on whether or not an alternate aerodrome has been designated in the flight plan.
more than that required at a destination aerodrome.
less than that required at a destination aerodrome.

variant.question: If the flap setting is changed from 10°  to 20° , V2MIN will

options.text: decrease if not limited by VMCA.
increase or decrease depending on weight.
increase
remain the same.

variant.question: At the same aircraft mass if a higher V1 was used then

options.text: TODR will decrease and ASDR increase.
TODR and ASDR will increase.
TODR will increase and ASDR decrease.
TODR will be unaffected and ASDR will increase.

variant.question:
If the aircraft rotates earlier and at a much faster rate than expected what is the likely reason?
 
1) The rotate speed, VR, has been miscalculated.
 
2) The stabilizer trim setting has been miscalculated.
 
3) The centre of gravity is too far forward.
 
4) The centre of gravity is too far aft.
 
5) The decision speed V1, has been miscalculated.
What happens to the take-off distance, assuming all other factors remain constant, if a take-off is performed in headwind conditions?

options.text: The take-off distance is shorter because the lift-off speed is reached earlier.
The take-off distance remains the same since ground speed is irrelevant.
The take-off distance remains the same because it the take-off distance depends on the air density only.
The take-off distance is longer because the headwind increases drag and therefore prevents the aircraft from accelerating.

variant.question:
The following parameters affect the take-off ground run:

1.decreasing take-off mass2.increasing take-off mass3.increasing density4.decreasing density5.increasing flap setting6.decreasing flap setting7.increasing pressure altitude8.decreasing pressure altitude
Which parameters will decrease the take-off ground run?
What will happen to the take-off distance required (1) and to the landing distance required (2), if the air density increases?

options.text: (1) decreases, (2) decreases
(1) increases, (2) increases
(1) decreases, (2) increases
(1) increases, (2) decreases

variant.question:
The following parameters positively affect the take-off ground run
 
1) decreasing take-off mass.
 
2) increasing take-off mass.
 
3) increasing density.
 
4) decreasing density.
 
5) increasing flap setting.
6) decreasing flap setting.
7) increasing pressure altitude.
8) decreasing pressure altitude.

Due to a pilot mistake, if on a particular flight the value of V~1~ used on take-off exceeds the correct value of V~1~, and an engine fails at a speed immediately above the correct value of V~1~ then:

options.text: the accelerate-stop distance will exceed the accelerate-stop distance available.
the one-engine-inoperative take-off distance may exceed the take-off distance available.
V2 may be too high so that climb performance decreases.
it may lead to over-rotation.

variant.question:
Assuming an engine failure during take-off, how will an increase of V1 affect TOM limited by TODA / limited by ASDA? 
TOM limited by TODA / limited by ASDA will...

options.text: increase / decrease.
not be affected / decrease.
not be affected / increase.
decrease / increase.

variant.question: If bleed-air systems are used during take-off, the take-off distance is

options.text: increased, as less thrust is available.
the same, as it does not on impact engine performance.
decreased, due to the lower acceleration.
decreased, as more fuel is burnt.

variant.question: The 2 seconds time interval during take-off between V~EF~ and V~1~ is used for:

options.text: recognition.
deciding (continue or abort).
calling ATC.
informing the cabin.

variant.question:
Which of the following will affect the level-off altitude during a drift-down?
 
1) outside air temperature
 
2) wind
 
3) distance to alternate airport
 
4) engine thrust
What is the factor for Class A aeroplanes, when determining the take-off distance and when considering a take-off from a dry runway with all engines operating?
The 1 seconds time interval during take-off between VEF and V1 is used for

options.text: recognition.
deciding (continue or abort).
informing the cabin.
calling ATC.

variant.question: Following a take-off calculation a range of decision speeds is found to be available with a maximum V1 of 150 KT and a minimum V1 of 142 KT. Which of the following statements would be correct in the event of an engine failure after the chosen V1?

options.text: Using a V1 of 150 KT compared to 142 KT will reduce the take-off distance and leave the climb performance unchanged.
Using a V1 of 142 KT compared to 150 KT will reduce the take-off distance and degrade the climb performance.
Using a V1 of 150 KT compared to 142 KT will reduce the take-off distance and improve the climb performance.
Using a V1 of 142 KT compared to 150 KT will reduce the take-off distance and leave the climb performance unchanged.

variant.question: What is the effect of using engine bleed air on the take-off distance?

options.text: Reduces thrust available and increases the take-off distance
Increases thrust available and increases the take-off distance
Reduces thrust available and decreases the take-off distance
Bleed air has no effect on take-off distance.

variant.question: For a given V~1~, an inoperative aeroplane antiskid on one wheel will result in an increased

options.text: accelerate stop distance.
ground roll distance.
take-off run distance.
take off distance.

variant.question: When the outside air temperature increases, then

options.text: the field length limited Take-off Mass and the climb limited Take-off Mass decreases.
the field length limited Take-off Mass decreases but the climb limited Take-off Mass increases.
the field length limited Take-off Mass increases but the climb limited Take-off Mass decreases.
the field length limited Take-off Mass and the climb limited Take-off Mass increases.

variant.question: When performing an increased V~2~ takeoff, what must we pay most attention to, regarding the increased V~1~ speed?

options.text: Stop distance may be compromised.
The new V1 may be above controllability limits.
We may not clear distant obstacles since the climb gradient will be reduced.
Braking efficiency will be reduced.

variant.question: When performing an increased V~2~ takeoff, what must we account for?

options.text: We need to recalculate V1 and VMBE to ensure that we are within limits
The reduced thrust will require a lower V1 and therefore a decrease in ASDR and TODR
TODR will decrease but ASDR will increase
Climb gradient will be reduced

variant.question: Compared with balanced-field calculations for an aerodrome with no stopway or clearway, the use of a clearway in the take-off calculations will:

options.text: Increase the field-length-limited take-off mass.
Not affect the value of the field-length-limited take-off mass.
Increase the value of V1.
Not affect the value of V1.

variant.question: Given the published EFB figures below, what would the consequence be if the pilot accidentally entered a value of 124 kt for V~1~? V~1~ V~2~ V~R~ 142 kt 142 kt 145 kt

options.text: TOD would increase significantly and the aircraft may not become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.
TOD would decrease significantly and the aircraft might not be able to get airborne before the end of the runway in case of engine failure.
TOD is not affected and the aircraft will not encounter any additional challenges in become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.
TOD is not affected though the aircraft may not become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.

variant.question: A pilot is operating his first flight on a longer variant of an aircraft type he currently flies. Due to the increased risk of a tailstrike, pilot decides to rotate at a slower (but still acceptable) rate. This will have an effect on (1) _____ TOR, (2) _____ TOD and (3) _____ climb gradient.

options.text: (1) Increased; (2) Increased; (3) Increased
(1) Decreased; (2) Increased; (3) Decreased
(1) Decreased; (2) Decreased; (3) Decreased
(1) Increased; (2) Decreased; (3) Increased

variant.question:
Landing Mass 35 000 kg 
 Flaps VREF 
 15 140 kt 
 30 135 kt 
 45 130 ktAn airplane is planned to land with a landing mass of 35 000 kg and it is fitted with 200 psi tyres. What is the minimum recommended flap setting on a wet runway usable in order to minimize the risk of hydroplaning?

options.text: Any flap speed is above the hydroplaning speed.

variant.question: An airline captain has recently started operating a longer variant of an aircraft type he currently flies. As a result, he decides to use a higher V~1 , ~V~R~ and V~2~ for the takeoff. What risks are involved?

options.text: Increased TOR
Reduced climb gradient
Increased risk of tail strike
Reduced Vmca

variant.question: For a Class A aeroplane what is the all engines take-off distance safety factor?
For a Class A aeroplane what is the all engines take-off distance safety factor?

What is the minimum flap setting the pilot should use, when considering a rejected take-off, to avoid hydroplaning if the airplane is fitted with 200 psi tyres?
How is V1 affected if T/O flaps 20° is chosen instead of T/O flaps 10°?

options.text: V1 decreases if not restricted by VMCA.
V1 increases in proportion to the angle at which the flaps are set.
V1 has no connection with T/O flap setting, as it is a function of runway length only.
V1 has the same value in both cases.

variant.question: How is V2 affected if T/O flaps 20°  is chosen instead of T/O flaps 10° ?

options.text: V2 decreases if not restricted by VMCA.
V2 increases in proportion to the angle at which the flaps are set.
V2 has no connection with T/O flap setting, as it is a function of runway length only.
V2 has the same value in both cases.
